title: Dark Mode Accessibility Regression
context: Dark mode became a must-have feature after iOS and Android added system-wide dark themes. Users love it — it feels modern, reduces eye strain in low light, and saves battery on OLED screens. Product teams rush to implement it. But dark mode doubles the design surface area. Every color, every contrast ratio, every component state needs to work in both themes. Teams that carefully tuned their light mode for WCAG AA contrast ratios often ship dark modes that fail accessibility standards. Low-contrast text on dark backgrounds, insufficient focus indicators, images with transparent backgrounds that disappear, and status colors that lose meaning against dark surfaces. The feature that was supposed to improve comfort creates accessibility regressions for the users who need good contrast most.
hypothesis: Dark mode is better for users' eyes and improves the experience.

dontIf: You haven't audited your dark mode for WCAG AA contrast ratios
Your design system doesn't have semantic color tokens that work in both themes
ifYouMust: Build a semantic color token system before implementing dark mode
Audit every component for contrast ratios in both themes
Test with screen readers and low-vision simulators in dark mode
Ensure focus indicators are visible against dark backgrounds
